nodes.text: The impact of retirement savings policies on total wealth accumulation depends on whether they change savings via active choice (price subsidies) or passive choice (automatic contributions)

Conceptual two-type model: population divided into active savers (optimize responses to price and quantity changes) and passive savers (set fixed pension contributions invariant to incentives); predictions: automatic contributions affect passive savers' pension balances whereas price subsidies affect active savers

Data and empirical design: administrative panel for Denmark 1995-2009 with 41 million person-year observations on retirement and taxable accounts; quasi-experimental designs exploit firm switches, a 1998 mandated savings plan (MSP) discontinuity, and a 1999 tax subsidy reform at the top tax cutoff

Definition of empirical estimands: pass-through of automatic contributions to total pensions and total saving (dP/dP E, d(P+S)/dP E), fraction active savers estimated as 1 - pass-through; crowd-out of subsidies measured as shifts between retirement accounts and from retirement to taxable saving
Employer pension variation (firm switches) approximates experiment holding total compensation fixed because employer contributions vary sharply across firms via collective bargaining

Finding — employer-provided automatic contributions: when workers move to firms with DKr 1 higher employer contribution, total saving rises by ~0.78 DKr and total pension contributions rise by ~0.95 DKr, implying pass-through ≈ 0.94 to pensions and ≈ 0.78 to total saving

Finding — government mandated savings plan (MSP) RD: the 1% MSP at income cutoff increased total pension contributions and total saving for those just above the cutoff with pass-through estimates near 0.85-1.27 depending on metric, indicating most individuals did not offset mandated contributions

Finding — 1999 capital pension subsidy reduction at top tax bracket: individual capital pension contributions fell sharply for treated group, with DD estimates showing a reduction of DKr 2,449 (≈48% of prior mean) and MPS fall of 0.021

Evidence interpretation: majority (≈85%) of individuals behave passively with respect to automatic contributions (do not offset increases), implying automatic contributions substantially raise total saving because many passive savers maintain taxable saving targets rather than consumption targets

Heterogeneity and active vs passive identification: only ≈19% of individuals actively responded to the 1999 subsidy reduction (most responses concentrated on extensive margin exits from capital pensions); active responders are older, wealthier, college-educated and more financially sophisticated

Crowd-out within retirement accounts: when capital pension subsidy was reduced, ~0.47-0.57 DKr of each DKr moved from capital to annuity pensions (partial within-retirement substitution) leaving total pension contributions to fall by ~0.43 DKr per DKr of reduced capital contributions

Crowd-out between retirement and taxable accounts: instrumental and threshold MPS estimates imply near-complete crowd-out of retirement contributions by taxable saving (point estimates near 0.98-1.20 DKr of taxable saving per DKr change in retirement contributions); adjusted estimates imply each DKr of government subsidy generated ≈0.01 DKr of net new saving (point estimate <1 cent) with 95% CI upper bound up to ~0.28 DKr under assumptions

Conclusion: automatic contributions (mandates/defaults) are more effective at increasing total saving than tax subsidies because subsidies induce few individuals to respond, respondents largely shift assets across accounts (high crowd-out), and passive savers (majority) remain unresponsive to price incentives

Policy implication and external validity: results support promoting automatic payroll-based contributions and defaults to raise retirement wealth; patterns are consistent with U.S. evidence but direct study in other countries is recommended
